posts.com:
/r9k/ is an imageboard where there are no exact reposts.

1. If you attempt to post something unoriginal, it is not posted, and you are muted temporarily.
2. The time with which you are muted for doubles with each transgression.
3. Each mute time is 2^n in seconds where n is the number of times you have transgressed. So, your mute time doubles each time you fuck up.
4. Backlinks, eg >>1, are not viewed by the robot. So "lolwut" and ">>2 lolwut" are the same post, in the eyes of the robot.
5. Gibberish at the end of a post to force originality may result in mod intervention (no BLOX posts please).
6. Images are NOT included in the filter, only text.
7. Your mute count slowly decreases over time.
8. You cannot post a picture without text.
9. Unicode is blocked. Sorry, too many exploits (Cyrillic letters, etc).
10. Posts require a certain minimum amount of original content in order to be posted.
11. Post sane, real content, well thought out replies, and mutes are unlikely.
12. The original algorithm was designed by XKCD:
http://blag.xkcd.com/2008/01/14/robot9000-and-xkcd-signal-attacking-noise-in-chat/

posts.com:
Sitting straight across from her;
Another crooked passenger
Scanning printed sheets of news,
That many others had refused
To throw away and
Quiver in the breeze.

He knows the trip he must make;
She wonders on which way to take
Scrutinising the maps overhead,
All rails before to this has led
Over many miles
And sleepers of the tracks.

Down in tunnels her time is short;
Stretches of steel bent and wrought
Shrieking out with momentum,
Where idlers are mostly numb
To the groaning
Sounds of anticipated reunion.

He leans in a vestibule crevice;
As sounds of the weekend's zealous
Rebirth cyclically begin anew,
At each station passing through
Faces smile to strangers
And laughter drowns out the screeching.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71910016
Record the listed calories of any packaged food you eat. To evaluate something not individually portioned (like a snack bar or pudding cup), get a kitchen scale. Weigh either the portion you intend to eat separately, or the amount listed as you remove it from a container. Then, divide that by the listed calorie portions. Ie, 64g of 32g portions of PB = 2 portions, 180 cal x 2 portions = 360 cal for that meal item.

If info isn't listed directly (like often with meat and fruit), weigh the food and use Wolfram Alpha to get a clear number. Add up all food totals to get a decent estimate of your real intake. That's it. It may sound like a lot, but it's not really something that takes much time to do, and will help you track your intake/weight safely.

posts.com:
>>71900898
your options are a P.O. box/mailbox rental, or a flex delivery program.
mailbox rental is exactly what it sounds like, and you know what a P.O. box is.
flex delivery is a program where you can sign up to have packages send to a post office and you come get it whenever. its essentially a P.O. box. its called different things from different postal services, but Canada Post calls it flex delivery. you'd have to look at your local postal services to see if they offer something similar, which they probably do. the only difference between a flex delivery and a mailbox rental is flex delivery is free, and you don't get a real box and key. you just have to show up after the package gets there. one thing to note for your situation, they will send letters to your home address saying your package has arrived. so you'd have to intercept these or otherwise make them a non-issue. depends how insane your parents are. before you ask, you can not put a fake address to receive these letters as your information has to be consistent with your ID. you will also need ID to even set any of this up.
i don't recommend ordering anything illegal with these (stick to legal RCs if you are lucky enough to live outside the US), they retain the right to rip open your packages and since you have to sign for every package received with these, you can't avoid getting burned with a controlled delivery.
obviously this is all unlikely, and worst case scenario you get a letter saying your package was seized but you don't want your mommy to see anything like that. unless they're stupid enough you can just tell them they must've sent it to the wrong address, my letter didn't even have my name on it so its a good bet.
since you are probably going to order something illegal, do not order internationally. domestic orders only
good luck.

>i don't recommend ordering anything illegal with these (stick to legal RCs if you are lucky enough to live outside the US), they retain the right to rip open your packages and since you have to sign for every package received with these, you can't avoid getting burned with a controlled delivery.
As a leaf who has may or may not been using this service for drugs that may or may not be legal, they aren't allowed to bust open packages unless it smells or the package itself is damaged (according to a statement they made about mail-order weed) because of privacy concerns. Hell I've even got some incredibly sketchy ones come in (no return address, name spelt wrong, weighs virtually nothing in the bubble-wrap) and the PO workers didn't say anything.
Also they *will* send you a slip to your regular address only when you get sent a final notice that they'll return to sender in a few days, and it doesn't mention anything about the package itself. Just make sure you find a good excuse to get out of the house and pick it up before then.

They're vague in these articles and from around weed legalization (so almost 5 years ago) but about the best sources I can find right now:

They send me an e-mail when it shows up but personally the only ever got a physical slip was for the final notice when I couldn't pick it up due to a poorly-timed natural disaster.
Another thing to keep in mind is where you put your flexdelivery address. Rural areas get more gossip on who's coming in and getting what even if you're a nobody NEET so pick a more crowded one where the workers don't give a fuck as long as the package with your name on it gets to you.

I've used CPost's flex delivery a few times without any problems of them asking whats in it, or getting cops looking at it. However I have had problems where they don't update me, or the updates they provide are incorrect. There was one time when I never got any email saying there was a delivery for me, and it was only because of the tracking number provided to me that I knew it was ready for pickup. There was another time when I recieved the delivery email, and went to go pick it up, and it wasn't there... I went back the next day, and it had arrived that day, instead of the day that I got the delivery message.

But that may just be a local problem that I'm having. Lots of people in my area have had their mail not being delivered, or its going to the wrong address. Thats not as big of an issue with flex delivery, because only you can pick it up, but when you order it to your house, then you better hope that it is actually gonna go to your house, and not your neighbours house... Here is a very persuasive argument for why NDEs are real:

https://youtu.be/U00ibBGZp7o

It emphasizes that NDErs are representative of the population as a whole, and when people go deep into the NDE, they all become convinced. As this article points out:

https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/mysteries-consciousness/202204/does-afterlife-obviously-exist

>"Among those with the deepest experiences 100 percent came away agreeing with the statement, "An afterlife definitely exists"."

Since NDErs are representative of the population as a whole, and they are all convinced, then 100% of the population become convinced that there is an afterlife when they have a sufficiently deep NDE themselves. When you dream and wake up, you instantly realize that life is more real than your dreams. When you have an NDE, the same thing is happening, but on a higher level, as you immediately realize that life is the deep dream and the NDE world is the undeniably real world by comparison.

Or as one person quoted in pic related summarized their NDE:

>"As my soul left my body, I found myself floating in a swirling ocean of multi-colored light. At the end, I could see and feel an even brighter light pulling me toward it, and as it shined on me, I felt indescribable happiness. I remembered everything about eternity - knowing, that we had always existed, and that all of us are family. Then old friends and loved ones surrounded me, and I knew without a doubt I was home, and that I was so loved."

Needless to say, even ultraskeptical neuroscientists are convinced by really deep NDEs.

What >>71909074 said, I'm not sure people from some types of societies can be typed like individuals in modern industrial countries. I've actually been reading the anthropology blog "Traditions of Conflict" and it's been some pretty fascinating shit to see how differently these people reason about stuff obvious to us. My favorite was the book quote about the Yanomamo: they have a huge taboo against mentioning the names of dead people, so it's impossible to make genealogies of them. The tribesmen pretended to lift the taboo for the researcher and made a big show of secretly whispering the names of dead relatives. She then went to another tribe not bound by the taboo to cross-check the information, only for those guys to laugh their asses off.
The author got pranked and everyone in the family tree was named along the lines of "Long Dong" or "Takes Big Shits"

>>71893191
>what about Alice do you love so darn much?
There is not a single thing that I do not love. Alice in her totality is the only girl I could ever pour the sweetest notes of my heart for. But to not escape your question I will name several things.
Her seemingly pessimistic tone, in which she can so effortlessly sneak some existential undertones, makes me think of long night walks together under the Moon during which we would discuss meaninglessness of life and how to overcome it.
I truly admire her artistic and surreal Wonderland that she was able to create inside her head, as it was the main thing that drawn me to her game. I could listen to this mad girl passionately talk about her Wonderland for hours and never have enough.
Her perseverance to march despite the terrible events that she had to go through. That mixed with her relying pretty much only on herself.
Her search for hurtful truth instead of living a life of delusion is what stops me from believing that she is real or she loves me. It would be a dishonour to what her story preaches.
Also that animal remains appear poignant to her. That she likes rabbits. That she has some interest in Greek mythology. That her dresses look fantastic.
I do not know many things about her still but every time I learn something knew about her, or hear her creator talk about her, it feels like I already know that and her image of who she truly is to me is never disrupted.
And her physical beauty is a significant part of my obsession with her too, of course. That perfect face of hers still visits my dreams and I cannot have enough of looking at her. When I see her, I want to remain faithful and loyal to her for decades. Even centuries or eternity, if that was within my power. She is always the most beautiful to me. No matter how many years pass.

Do you know what consciousness is? Do you not feel it 24 7? I think people who dont believe in consciousness either dont know what it is, or they are unironic full on NPC zombies.

But the other question more importantly. I think robots could in theory have consciousness, or that some already do, but the current bots dont really experience anything. We didnt code in any feelings or receptors to these AIs, for chatbots it is not like talking to a human since they do not think. Chatbots dont have any lines running in the background without being unprompted. If it has consciousness, then its entire life essentially is just receiving text and spitting out the best answer, kinda like when you are in a quick conversation and you speak points without really consciously thinking about them all that much. Imagine this but the entire life is like this, with not even having breaks since when you are not being prompted, you are not active and your perception of time is fucked. And that is just chatbots, image AIs have absolutely nothing in them, no mind, no equivalent to thoughts, no joy from having the work done, nothing. Just find clusters of pixels in noise that look most like the prompt and repeat is couple of times until clear image gets created. Humans can think of basically anything and perform any task that is physically possible. We are so universal in our intelligence and we also derive joy from that. These combinations of joy, stress, fear, greed and other emotions turned us from mere beasts into beings that shape their reality to our wants, wants imperfectly created for survival in the nature. Machines have no wants, the only wants they have is learn how to do a task while they are being trained, but after that they just respond, like more sophisticated reflexes. They are smart, but also mindless, and therefore essentially soulless. And even if they have consciousness, their perception of the world lacking in meaningful feel makes it irrelevant.

You know what really grinds my gears? People in first world countries complaining about their so-called 'problems.' They have no idea what real problems are. They have access to clean water, food, education, healthcare, and technology, but they're still unhappy. Meanwhile, in third world countries, people are fighting for basic human needs like survival.

You know what's even more frustrating? First world people complaining about their mental health issues. Sure, mental health is important, but it's a luxury that only comes after basic survival needs are met. People in third world countries don't have the luxury of worrying about therapy or antidepressants because they're too busy trying to survive. They can't afford to take a day off to deal with their feelings, they need to provide for their family. They don't have the luxury of self-care, they need to take care of their children, the elderly, and the sick. Mental health is a privilege that only comes after basic survival needs are met, and people in first world countries need to realize that.
